content:
Would somebody who understands this stuff explain what the intuition is behind the word "condensed" in condensed mathematics? I'm translating the Wikipedia article on Lean (which admittedly is not very comprehensive but is a good starting point) from English to Chinese, and I couldn't find a Chinese translation of "condensed mathematics".

Which of the following definitions (from Cambridge Dictionary) is most relevant?

  1. (of a liquid) made thicker by removing some of the water
  2. (of a piece of writing) made shorter in length
  3. made from a gas into a liquid or solid state

For those of you who also read Chinese, here are some possible words: 濃縮、精煉、提煉、精簡、縮簡、減縮、簡練、凝固、凝結、凝練、集中。I welcome other suggestions. Thank you in advance.
as I understand it, if profinite sets are "clouds of dust" then condensed sets are clouds of dust which have been condensed (in the sense of 1 and/or 3)
Is "distillation" the right intuition at all, or is it more about moving the dust particle closer to each other?
IMO, "distillation" does have some connotations of "removing stuff", and thus not as appropriate in this context.
Leaning towards 凝結數學, excluding all those that imply removing stuff. (See below)

https://www.bananaspace.org/wiki/%E8%AE%B2%E4%B9%89:%E5%87%9D%E8%81%9A%E6%80%81%E6%95%B0%E5%AD%A6

is this the same condensed mathematics that you're looking at? I think they borrowed the term directly from "condensed matter physics", but maybe Chinese mathematicians have already picked up on it to use 凝聚态数学

I'm definitely not qualified to comment on the correctness of the translation but here's what they have (in that page):
image.png
Based on what I've heard in Taiwan (if any), I think 凝聚體數學 / 凝態數學 is the most common, analogous to the physics term.
Winston Yin (尹維晨) has marked this topic as resolved.
@Leonardo de Moura and @Kevin Buzzard also have Chinese names: 萊昂納多·德·莫拉 and 凱文·巴扎德 but no Chinese Wikipedia articles yet.
